awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Manipulating the Innate Immune Response to Improve Gene Therapy
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Elmer, Jacob   
Proposal No: 1651837

The goal of this project is to improve gene therapy by identifying and modifying the genes involved in the immune response to extraneous DNA in several cancer cell lines. Such an approach is expected to enhance gene delivery by inhibiting the target genes with both small molecule inhibitors and inhibitor proteins.

A somatic cell's first line of defense against viral infection is the innate immune response (IIR) consisting of several enzymes and receptors that actively seek out pathogenic molecules within the cell.  Activation of the IIR by cytoplasmic DNA can then induces inflammation, inhibits protein translation, and even cause the host cell to self-destruct.   While all of these reactions defend the cell from viruses, they can significantly hinder gene therapy.  Indeed, most gene therapy treatments deliver therapeutic DNA to the cytoplasm, where it unintentionally activates the IIR.  The goal of this project is to improve gene therapy by addressing this problem.  We will begin by identifying the exact proteins and genes involved in the innate immune response to cytoplasmic DNA in a variety of cancer cell lines.  Gene delivery will then be enhanced by inhibiting those genes/proteins with small molecule inhibitors and/or viral inhibitor proteins.  As an alternative to inhibition of the IIR, transgene expression will be increased by using promoters that are known to be activated by the IIR.  Altogether, these experiments will simultaneously improve gene therapy and increase our understanding of the innate immune response to cytoplasmic DNA. In addition, this project will also include a series of year-round outreach activities that will directly benefit the community.  For example, the PI will organize an outreach program that enables underrepresented high school students to perform gene delivery and biochemical engineering experiments at Villanova.  The PI will also create a summer research experience program for high school teachers that allows them to perform gene therapy experiments in the PI?s lab and then share those experiences with their classes in the fall semester.  Finally, each of the experiments conducted in this project will also be recorded and used to create educational/training videos.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
NSF: CAREER: Manipulating the Innate Immune Response to Improve Gene Therapy

Intellectual Merit

The goal of this proposal was to determine how a host cell responds to gene delivery and then use that knowledge to design strategies to improve gene therapy by inhibiting those host cell responses.  Specifically, we used a technique called mRNA-sequencing to identify all the genes that are expressed at a higher level after a new gene is delivered to the cells. [1]  This allowed us to identify a set of genes that might be responsible for degrading, sequestering, or otherwise repressing the new gene in cancer cell types [1] and in the T cells that are commonly used for CAR-T cell therapies against leukemia. [2]  We then leveraged these findings to screen several small molecule inhibitors that are known to inhibit the targets we identified, which would hopefully make the cells more permissive to gene delivery.  These efforts identified several drugs that could increase the expression of foreign genes, including iCRT14, an inhibitor of the beta catenin/TCF4 complex that enhanced gene expression 10-fold or more in multiple different cell types. [3] Finally, we have recently identified IFI16 and other host cell proteins as repressors of gene expression in T cells, but the inhibition of those targets will have to be the focus of future projects as this one has ended.

1)     Warga E, Anderson J, Tucker M, Harris E, Elmer J. Transcriptomic Analysis of the Innate Immune Response to in vitro Transfection of Plasmid DNA. Molecular Therapy – Nucleic Acids. 2023. 14(31):43-56. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.omtn.2022.11.025

2)     Harris E, Zimmerman D, Warga E, Bamezai A, Elmer J.  Non-viral gene delivery to T cells with Lipofectamine LTX.  Biotech. & BioEng. 2021. 118(4):1693-1706.  https://doi.org/10.1002/bit.27686

3)     Spivack K, Muzzelo C, Hall M, Warga E, Neely C, Slepian H, Cunningham A, Tucker M, Elmer J.  Enhancement of transgene expression by the b-catenin inhibitor iCRT14.  Plasmid. 2021. 114:102556.  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.plasmid.2021.102556

Broader Impacts

In addition to our work in the lab, we also conducted multiple outreach activities, including a summer research experience for teachers (SRET), a lab experience for high school students that spanned several weekends as part of the Villanova Engineering, Science, and Technology Enrichment and Development program (VESTED), and several training videos that were uploaded to YouTube.  The most popular YouTube videos have gained over 40,000 views (e.g., https://youtu.be/bjuTrHaCxJ4?si=6SLVtvXBXfB-v4OG).  In the VESTED program, Dr. Elmer hosted approximately 10 high school students in his lab over the course of 7 Saturdays in the winter (except for 2020 and 2021 when the program was hosted virtually on zoom due to the pandemic).  The students worked on different projects in the lab each year, ranging from expression of a valuable human enzyme in bacteria (alpha galactosidase) to developing a 3D printed sensor that could be used to detect antibiotic resistance in bacteria.  Finally, Dr. Elmer hosted a total of 7 teachers from local high schools in his lab during July and August each summer.  These teachers assisted Dr. Elmer in real experiments related to this project and worked with him to develop lessons that they then brought back to their classrooms to share with their students during the following year.


Last Modified: 10/27/2023
Modified by: Jacob Elmer
